children.name: to find sth you need or want
find a1
children.definition: find/faɪnd/  to find something that you need, such as a job or a place to live: tìm (việc, nơi ở)
examples: ▪ i really need to find a better job.
▪ it took us half an hour to find somewhere to park.
▪ jenny found an apartment in brooklyn.

children.name: locate b2
children.definition: locate/ləʊˈkeɪtǁˈləʊkeɪt/  formal or written to find out where something is - used especially in official or technical contexts: tìm thấy
examples: ▪ investigators searched through the plane’s wreckage for several hours before locating the flight recorder.
▪ if you have difficulty locating a particular book, please ask one of the librarians for assistance.
location/ləʊˈkeɪʃən/ [uncountable noun]
▪ techniques for the location of tumours have improved greatly over the last twenty years.

children.name: dig out x
children.definition: dig out especially british to find something you have not seen for a long time, or that may not be easy to find, especially in order to give it to someone who has asked for it: đào ra
examples: ▪ it seems like every time grandma comes over we have to dig out the family photos.
▪ i took the opportunity to dig out a few facts and figures about this remote island.
▪ i have her address somewhere -- i’ll dig it out for you when i get time.

children.name: to find sth new and important
find a1
children.definition: find/faɪnd/  to find something important that no one knew about before, especially information or a way of doing something: tìm ra
examples: ▪ medical researchers are determined to find a cure for cancer.
▪ it’s crucial that we find cleaner ways of generating electricity.
▪ bodies up to 2,000 years old have been found buried in the peat bogs of central england.

children.name: discover b1
children.definition: discover/dɪsˈkʌvəʳ/  to find an object, a substance, a place, information etc, that is important and that no one knew about before: khám phá ra
examples: ▪ the planet pluto was discovered in 1930.
▪ australian researchers have discovered a substance in coffee that acts like morphine.

children.name: make a discovery b2
children.definition: make a discovery/ˌmeɪk ə dɪsˈkʌvəri/  to find something important, interesting, or surprising that no one knew about before: khám phá
examples: ▪ hawking made many discoveries about the nature of stars.
▪ carlo rubbia, who led the team of scientists that made the discovery, received the nobel prize in 1984.
▪ amazing discoveries have been made by anthropologists excavating in the rift valley.
▪ an important discovery was made by mendel in the mid-nineteenth century.

children.name: unearth x
children.definition: unearth to find something that was hidden or kept secret for a long time, especially information: khai quật
examples: ▪ investigators have unearthed new evidence about the possible cause of the crash.
▪ the incredible story was unearthed by reporters at the ‘post’.
▪ his research unearthed new information about the origins of the hiv virus.

children.name: turn up x
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive phrasal verb not usually in passive]
children.definition: turn up to find something interesting or useful, especially information, while you are searching carefully: tìm ra
examples: ▪ after seven months on the case, the police failed to turn up any real clues.
▪ a thorough examination of the company’s account books turned up several interesting facts.

children.name: to find sb/sth that is lost
find a1
children.definition: find/faɪnd/  to find someone or something that you have lost: tìm kiếm (người, vật đã mất đi)
examples: ▪ i’ve looked everywhere, but i can’t find my sunglasses.
▪ have you found your passport yet?
▪ the murder weapon was found outside the house.
▪ luis was gone, and she had no way of ever finding him again.

children.name: turn up x
children.definition: turn up if something that is lost turns up, someone finds it later in a place where they did not expect it to be: "xuất hiện"
examples: được tìm thấy, quay về
▪ don’t worry about your earrings - i’m sure they’ll turn up sooner or later.
▪ have those files turned up yet?

children.name: trace c1
children.definition: trace to find sb/sth by acarefulprocess ofaskinga lot of people for information: lần ra, tìm ra , truy tìm
examples: police are trying to trace a red van, which several witnesses reported seeing near the scene of the crime.
the cash was eventually traced to a prominent paris lawyer.
philips hired a private detective to trace his daughter, who had been missing for two months.

children.name: track down c1
children.definition: track down to find sb/sth that is difficult to find, by searching or by making inquiries in several different places: truy tìm
examples: ▪ the police have had a difficult time tracking down corbin.
▪ i have copies of the documents but haven’t managed to track down the originals.
▪ the president vowed to track down those responsible for the bombing.
▪ it took alvin quite a while to track her down, but he eventually found her.

children.name: be difficult to find a1
children.definition: be difficult to find/hard to find if sb/sth that you need is difficult to find or hard to find, you cannot easily find them because there are not many of them or they are well hidden: khó tìm
examples: ▪ taxis are hard to find at that time of night.
▪ what we wanted was a house with a big garden -- something that was difficult to find in the middle of a city.

children.name: elusive c2
children.definition: elusive an elusive person or animal is difficult to find, often because they do not want to be found: khó bắt, khó tìm
examples: ▪ the gray fox is a very shy elusive creature.
▪ a cure for the disease has proven to be elusive.
▪ we repeatedly tried to contact the manager, an elusive man who was never in his office.

children.name: to unexpectedly find sth that you were not looking for
find a1
children.definition: find khám phá
examples: we found a lovely seafood restaurant by the harbour.

children.name: come across b2
children.definition: come across to find sth unexpectedly when you are not looking for it but are doing sth else: tình cờ thấy
examples: i came across an interesting news item in yesterday’s ‘times’.
digging in the garden, she came across some pieces of bone.

children.name: stumble on c2
children.definition: stumble on/across to find sth by chance and unexpectedly, especially sth that was secret or that no one knew before: tìm thấy
examples: the officers stumbled across the drugs when they stopped moyers for a routine traffic violation.
fleming was carrying out other research when he stumbled on penicillin.
some people believe that jenkins was murdered by government agents because he stumbled across a military secret.

children.name: happen upon x
children.definition: chance upon/happen upon written to find a place or thing that you were not deliberately looking for, or meet sb you did not know you would meet, especially when you consider this a good or lucky thing to have happened: phát hiện
examples: we happened upon a beautiful little hotel about an hour outside of tours.
i was walking home from the station when i happened upon richard.
leafing through a magazine, i chanced upon a photo of an old high school friend, robert mason.

children.name: discover b1
children.definition: discover khám phá ra, tìm ra
examples: the body was discovered by a man walking his dog.
it wasn’t until i got to university that i discovered poetry.

children.name: discovery b2
children.definition: discovery a fact or thing that someone finds out about, when it was not known about before: khám phá
examples: among the discoveries of the late nineteenth century were several new chemical elements, including radium.
new archaeological discoveries prove the existence of an ancient civilization in the indus valley.
discovery about
the hubble telescope allowed astronomers to make significant discoveries about our galaxy.
discovery that
the discovery that bees can communicate with each other
make a discoveryby making new discoveries we expand our understanding of the natural world.
lead to a discoveryit was pure chance that led to the discovery.
a new discoverynew discoveries are being made all the time.
a recent discoverythe recent discovery of frozen water on the moon
a great/major/important discoverythe archaeologists had made an important discovery.
a scientific/medical etc discoverythe book covers the major scientific discoveries of the last century.
an exciting discoverythe existence of the new solar system was a very exciting discovery.
a surprising/unexpected discoverytheir work led to some surprising discoveries.
a startling discovery(= very surprising )when they examined the virus, they made a startling discovery.
an accidental/chance discovery(= happening by chance )some of the tombs were the result of chance discoveries.
a grim discovery(= an unpleasant and sad discovery such as finding a dead body )police made the grim discovery while they were searching the house.

children.name: real find x
children.definition: be a real find if sb/sth is a real find, you were lucky to find them because they are very good, useful, or interesting: phát hiện tuyệt vời
examples: that little greek restaurant was a real find.
last month the club signed on a new player, nate tompkins, who has already proved to be a real find.

children.name: discovery b2
children.definition: discovery b2 when someone discovers something
examples: discovery of
the discovery of oil in alaska

children.name: get hold of b2
children.definition: get hold ofuk(usget ahold of)
examples: informalto find someone or obtain something
_where can i get hold of some stamps?
_how can i get ahold of chris?

children.name: detect c1
children.definition: detectverbdò ra; tìm ra; khám phá ra; phát hiện ra
examples: to notice something that is partly hidden or not clear, or to discover something, especially using a special method
_some sounds cannot be detected by the human ear.
_financial experts have detected signs that the economy is beginning to improve.
detectverb[ t ]
to discover something, usually using special equipment
_high levels of lead were detected in the atmosphere.
_radar equipment is used to detect (= find the position of) enemy aircraft.
_detect a symptom of disease phát hiện ra triệu chứng bệnh

children.name: trace c1
children.definition: traceverbfindtruy nguyên, tìm thấy nguồn gốc của (cái gì)
examples: to find the origin of something
_the phone company were unable to trace the call.
_no one has yet been able to trace the source of the rumour.

children.name: strike c2
children.definition: strikeverbdiscoverdò đúng, đào đúng (mạch dầu, mạch mỏ...)
examples: [ t ]struck,struckto discover a supply of oil, gas or gold underground
_the first person to strikeoilin theuswas edwin laurentine drake.

children.name: put your finger on sth c2
